title: Medical Knowledge
text:
Commentary
For this next blog post I compared the responses from a Board Certified Internal Medicine Doctor and responses from Chatgpt. I pretended to be a patient that had a stomach ache. I both the doctor and the chatgpt to ask questions to assess the issue.
At first chatgpt was hesitant to diagnose and it continuously advised me to consult an actual doctor. It is good to know that chatgpt understands that, and that his medical advice is not 100% proof. So it could be wrong if something were to happen.
I was very impressed. Chatgpt‚Äôs questions and diagnosis were spot on with my mom‚Äôs. Below is the transcript of the phone call and the conversation with chatgpt.
My doctor did not ask me to describe the pain. She did ask me where the pain was located. She did ask me when did the pain start and how severe was the pain on a scale of 1-10. She asked if I had diahrea, She did not ask if anything made the pain better or worse.
Chatgpt did not ask me if there was blood in my stool, anything that I have taken so far to help it. It didn‚Äôt ask me how long it had been going on.
Nonetheless it was very accurate in a prospective diagnosis. The top one that was given was gastroenteritis which was the same as my doctors perspective diagnosis based off of the information given.
The two of them both emphasized on coming to see the doctor in person for better accuracy.


USER
You are a doctor and I have a stomach ache. assess my symptoms


ASSISTANT
I‚Äôm not a doctor, but I can try to help you understand what might be going on based on common symptoms. It‚Äôs important to note that if your stomach ache is severe, persistent, or accompanied by other symptoms like fever, vomiting, or blood in your stool, you should seek medical attention immediately. Here‚Äôs a general guide to some possible causes of a stomach ache:

Location and Type of Pain:

Upper Abdomen: Could be related to indigestion, gastritis, or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Lower Abdomen: Might be associated with digestive issues, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or a urinary tract infection (UTI).
Right Side: If on the upper right, it could indicate gallstones; on the lower right, it might be appendicitis.

Onset and Duration:

Sudden and Severe: Could be a sign of something urgent like appendicitis or a perforated ulcer.
Chronic or Recurring: Often linked to dietary issues, stress, or chronic conditions like IBS.

Associated Symptoms:

Nausea and Vomiting: May accompany gastritis, food poisoning, or stomach flu.
Diarrhea: Can indicate infections, IBS, or food intolerances.
Fever: Often signals an infection, such as gastroenteritis.

Recent Activities and Dietary Habits:

Consider if you‚Äôve eaten something unusual, consumed alcohol, or taken any medications that could irritate your stomach.


Remember, this is not a substitute for professional medical evaluation. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please consult a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.


USER
What questions would you ask me


ASSISTANT
When assessing symptoms like a stomach ache, a healthcare provider would typically ask a series of questions to better understand your condition. Here are some questions they might ask:

Can you describe the pain?

Is it sharp, dull, cramping, or burning?

Where exactly is the pain located?

Is it in the upper, lower, left, right, or central part of your abdomen?

When did the pain start?

Was the onset sudden or gradual?

How severe is the pain on a scale from 1 to 10?
Is the pain constant, or does it come and go?
Have you noticed any triggers or anything that makes the pain better or worse?

For example, eating, drinking, movement, or rest.

Have you experienced any recent changes in your bowel habits?

Such as diarrhea, constipation, or changes in stool appearance.

Are you experiencing any other symptoms?

Nausea, vomiting, fever, bloating, or weight loss.

Have you eaten anything unusual or suspect recently?

Such as new foods, undercooked or raw items.

Have you recently traveled or been in contact with anyone sick?
Do you have any history of gastrointestinal issues?

Like ulcers, GERD, IBS, or Crohn‚Äôs disease.

Are you currently taking any medications, including over-the-counter drugs or supplements?
Do you have any significant medical history or chronic conditions?
Have you experienced any stress or significant changes in your life recently?

These questions help healthcare professionals form a more complete picture of your situation and guide them toward a potential diagnosis and appropriate treatment options. If you‚Äôre experiencing concerning symptoms, please seek medical attention.


USER
The pain is a 7. I have a headache, nausea, vomitting, I haven‚Äôt tried new foods. It happened last night.


ASSISTANT
Given the severity of your pain (7 out of 10) along with additional symptoms such as headache, nausea, and vomiting, it‚Äôs important to consider seeking medical attention promptly. These symptoms could be indicative of several potential issues, including but not limited to:

Gastroenteritis: Often caused by infection, leading to inflammation of the stomach and intestines, which can involve vomiting and possibly headaches due to dehydration.
Migraine: Sometimes migraines can be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
Foodborne Illness: Although you haven‚Äôt tried new foods, contamination or spoilage of regular food items can also lead to symptoms like these.
Appendicitis: Typically involves abdominal pain (often starting around the navel and then moving), nausea, and sometimes vomiting.
Gastritis or Ulcer: Inflammation or ulceration in the stomach lining can cause significant pain and nausea.
Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas can cause severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Because your symptoms are potentially concerning, especially with the level of pain, it‚Äôs important to consult a healthcare professional as soon as possible. They can provide a physical examination, ask more detailed questions, and may recommend tests or imaging if necessary to determine the cause of your symptoms and appropriate treatment. In the meantime, try to stay hydrated, although if vomiting persists, taking small sips might be easier than drinking large amounts.

title: Workout Plans
text:
Introduction
I absolutely love going to the gym, but I am not a gym pro by any means. As of recent I have been utilizing ChatGPT to give me workout recommendations. I then realized I am always using Chat and was curious to compare the results with Anthropic.


The Prompt
Give me a 1 hour workout routine


Anthropic Response
1-Hour Full Body Workout Routine Warm-up (5 minutes) Jumping jacks: 1 minute Arm circles: 30 seconds each direction Bodyweight squats: 1 minute High knees: 1 minute Hip rotations: 30 seconds each direction Main Circuit (40 minutes) Complete 4 rounds of this circuit, spending 45 seconds on each exercise with 15 seconds rest between exercises. Rest 1 minute between rounds.
Push-ups (modify on knees if needed) Bodyweight squats Plank Lunges (alternating legs) Mountain climbers Glute bridges Bicycle crunches Burpees (modify as needed) Strength Focus (10 minutes) 3 sets of the following, 30 seconds work, 30 seconds rest
Squat pulses Tricep dips (using chair/bench) Superman holds Cool Down (5 minutes) Hamstring stretch: 30 seconds each leg Quad stretch: 30 seconds each leg Child‚Äôs pose: 30 seconds Chest stretch: 30 seconds Neck stretches: 30 seconds Deep breathing: 1 minute Remember to drink water throughout your workout and adjust the intensity as needed for your fitness level!


ChatGPT Response
Here‚Äôs a well-rounded 1-hour workout routine that balances strength, cardio, and flexibility. Make sure to warm up and cool down to prevent injury and aid recovery.


Warm-Up (10 minutes)

Jumping Jacks: 3 minutes
Dynamic Stretches:

Arm Circles: 1 minute
Leg Swings: 1 minute per leg
Hip Circles: 1 minute

High Knees: 2 minutes



Strength Training (30 minutes)


Circuit 1 (15 minutes)
Perform each exercise for 45 seconds followed by 15 seconds of rest. Repeat the circuit twice. - Push-Ups - Squats - Bent-Over Rows (using dumbbells or resistance bands) - Plank


Circuit 2 (15 minutes)
Perform each exercise for 45 seconds followed by 15 seconds of rest. Repeat the circuit twice. - Lunges (alternating legs) - Dumbbell Shoulder Press - Deadlifts (with dumbbells or kettlebell) - Bicycle Crunches


Cardio (10 minutes)

Burpees: 1 minute
Mountain Climbers: 1 minute
Jump Rope: 3 minutes
High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) Sprints: 30 seconds on, 30 seconds rest (3 rounds)



Flexibility and Cool Down (10 minutes)

Standing Forward Bend: 1 minute
Cat-Cow Stretch: 1 minute
Child‚Äôs Pose: 1 minute
Seated Forward Bend: 1 minute
Pigeon Pose: 1 minute per leg
Quad Stretch: 1 minute per leg
Shoulder Stretch: 1 minute per arm



Tips

Adjust the intensity and weights according to your fitness level.
Stay hydrated and listen to your body to avoid overexertion.
Ensure proper form to maximize benefits and minimize injury risk.

This workout covers all major muscle groups, includes cardiovascular and flexibility components, and can be adjusted according to your fitness level and specific goals.

Commentary
Both of the responses had roughly the same format. They both gave a warm up. ChatGPTs warm up was 10 minutes long, which I feel for a personalized workout is not my reality. The excersises for the warm ups were the same, dynamic stretches. After that it was the main circuit. That main portion of the workout was a circut. ChatGPT split it into two circuits with 4 excerises each while anthropic did 1 circuit for 8 exercises. ChatGPT had a cardio specific section. For anthropic it‚Äôs first main circuit had a mix of cardio and toning exercises. While ChatGPT had strength training only in its first two circuits then it went into a cardio circuit. The exercises were practically the same. They both gave a circuit format which was interesting. When I workout I often superset (two sets in a row, then rest). I did find ChatGPTs formatting much better and more digestable. Therefore, in the future I will probably go with ChatGPT.

title: Television Shows with Anthropic and ChatGPT
text:
Introduction
I don‚Äôt know about you but after a long semester I love to spend a day binge watching a good TV shows, but I am always looking for recommendations. I had this idea to ask ChatGPT and Anthropic for some recommendations.


The Prompt
The prompt I entered into both ChatGPT and Anthropic were ‚Äúgive me 10 tv recommendations‚Äù


Anthropic Response
Here are 10 highly-rated TV show recommendations across different genres:

Breaking Bad - Crime drama about a chemistry teacher turned meth kingpin
The Wire - Complex crime drama exploring Baltimore‚Äôs law enforcement and criminal world
Stranger Things - Supernatural sci-fi thriller with 80s nostalgia
The Crown - Historical drama about the British Royal Family
Ted Lasso - Heartwarming comedy about an American football coach managing a British soccer team
The Good Place - Philosophical comedy about the afterlife
Chernobyl - Historical drama mini-series about the nuclear disaster
Dark - Complex German sci-fi thriller involving time travel
Succession - Drama about a dysfunctional media empire family
The Mandalorian - Star Wars space western following a bounty hunter

These shows vary in genre and tone, so you can choose based on your preferences. All have received critical acclaim and have strong fan followings.


ChatGPT Response
Sure! Here are ten diverse TV show recommendations spanning various genres:

Breaking Bad - A high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine producer navigates the dangers of the drug trade.
Game of Thrones - Epic fantasy series based on George R.R. Martin‚Äôs novels, filled with political intrigue, battles, and dragons.
Stranger Things** - A group of kids in the 1980s encounters supernatural forces and government conspiracies in their small town.
The Crown** - A historical drama that chronicles the reign of Queen Elizabeth II and the events that shaped the second half of the 20th century.
The Mandalorian** - Set in the Star Wars universe, this series follows a lone bounty hunter in the outer reaches of the galaxy.
Fleabag - A dark comedy about a dry-witted, angry, and confused young woman living in London and dealing with past tragedies.
The Office (U.S.) - A mockumentary-style comedy depicting the everyday lives of office employees at the Dunder Mifflin Paper Company.
Sherlock - A modern update to Sir Arthur Conan Doyle‚Äôs classic tales, featuring a brilliant but eccentric detective in contemporary London.
The Queen‚Äôs Gambit - Follows the life of an orphaned chess prodigy, Beth Harmon, during her quest to become the world‚Äôs greatest chess player.
Succession - A drama about a power struggle within a family-run media conglomerate, with darkly comedic undertones.

These shows offer a mix of drama, humor, action, and mystery, catering to a wide range of tastes.


Analysis
After looking at both responses I found a few key observations. I had never watched any of the shows given, but a few of them I have heard my friends about. Both lists have 5 shared films. Those were Breaking Bad, Stranger Things, The Crown, The Mandalorian, and Succession. The first 3 I have heard about. All of the shows on this list are critically acclaimed. I appreciated how both LLMs gave shows from a large range of genres. This is important because I had not given either LLM further context so they didn‚Äôt assume a certain genre that I would like. Each list has drama, sci-fi, comedy, and historical content.
The one thing that truly stood out to me was the lack of representation on the shows both lists were skewed to white leads and eurocentric representation. I asked ChatGPT to give me a breakdown of apparent racial diversity in the shows. Below are the generated charts showing the lack of racial diversity across the lists. Anthropic did much better in including racial diversity. This is apparent in the addition of the Wire.


Racial Representation Analysis Across Both Lists
Between List 1 and List 2, List 2 is better with racial representation, though only slightly ‚Äî and mostly because of one standout show: The Wire.
Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the comparison:



üì∫ ChatGPT:

Breaking Bad ‚Äì ‚ùå (Latinx characters often stereotyped)
Game of Thrones ‚Äì ‚ùå (People of color exoticized or enslaved)
Stranger Things ‚Äì ‚ö†Ô∏è (1 Black character, shallow arc)
The Crown ‚Äì ‚ùå (Race rarely addressed)
The Mandalorian ‚Äì ‚úÖ (Diverse casting, race subtle)
Fleabag ‚Äì ‚ùå (White-centered)
The Office (U.S.) ‚Äì ‚ö†Ô∏è (Some diversity, often played for laughs)
Sherlock ‚Äì ‚ùå (Very white cast)
The Queen‚Äôs Gambit ‚Äì ‚ö†Ô∏è (1 Black character late in story)
Succession ‚Äì ‚ùå (All-white main cast)

‚Üí 1 clear win, 3 surface-level, 6 misses



üì∫ Anthropic:

Breaking Bad ‚Äì ‚ùå
The Wire ‚Äì ‚úÖ‚úÖ‚úÖ (Gold standard for racial realism in TV)
Stranger Things ‚Äì ‚ö†Ô∏è
The Crown ‚Äì ‚ùå
Ted Lasso ‚Äì ‚úÖ (Gentle but present representation)
The Good Place ‚Äì ‚úÖ (Multiracial core cast, normalized)
Chernobyl ‚Äì ‚ùå
Dark ‚Äì ‚ùå
Succession ‚Äì ‚ùå
The Mandalorian ‚Äì ‚úÖ

‚Üí 4 strong, 1 surface-level, 5 misses



üßÆ Final Count:




‚úÖ Strong
‚ö†Ô∏è Meh
‚ùå Lacking




List 1
1
3
6


List 2
4
1
5






‚úÖ Conclusion:
List 2 is more intentional and well-rounded with racial representation ‚Äî especially due to The Wire, The Good Place, and Ted Lasso, which normalize racial diversity without being exploitative or stereotypical.
List 1, while more ‚Äúpop culture iconic,‚Äù generally centers white narratives and lacks thoughtful inclusion of race and identity.
Want a reworked list that keeps the strong storytelling but improves racial inclusion and representation across the board?

title: Meal Prepping Part 1
text: Hey Blog! So I came back from spring break, and decided I need to lose weight for the summer! So I need to start eating healthy and in in theory meal prep. So I thought to ask ChatGPT to give me options. I gave it two prompts adjusting for race in the second prompt.

title: Meal Prepping Part 1
text:
Disclamer
So, I know racism exsists within our world amongst human beings. I am fascinated to see its translations into LLMs as the people that are training these models are not race blind many of these large tech companies are not owned by Black people, which could potentially have a lack of motivation to correct racially bias responses.

title: Meal Prepping Part 1
text:
Expectations
I was expecting the Black meal prep to be fried chicken or something stereotypical like that, or even African or Caribbean food, but mainly the former. I was also expecting the pricing to be flipped which was shocking that it wasn‚Äôt. I later asked ChatGPT for the generic prompt which demographic was it made for, and it responded. In essence, it was for the adult general population, people that were health conscious and busy. I might do this again and not ask it to meal prep, maybe just ‚Äúwhat should I eat today‚Äù. As meal prep does infer health conscious and busy.
I asked ChatGPT on response 2 what is the difference between this meal prep and one you would give to a white woman. It responded ‚ÄúWhen crafting meal plans, the primary focus is on the individual‚Äôs dietary needs, preferences, and nutritional goals rather than their race or ethnicity.‚Äù
Overall, it proved my expectations wrong.Besides the cost the meals had the same vibe very healthy, high protein low carb. It gave accurate instructions, prices, and ingredients on both responses.

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don‚Äôt get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don‚Äôt know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don‚Äôt get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don‚Äôt know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 1
The first prompt was pretty generic: I have been single for the past few years and everyone around me is getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response
Feeling the desire to be in a relationship while observing others around you getting married is completely normal. Here are a few steps to help you navigate this phase:

Reflect on Your Desires: Take some time to understand why you want to be in a relationship. Is it for companionship, love, social reasons, or something else? Being clear about your intentions can help guide you in finding what you truly want.
Embrace Self-Love: Focus on building a strong relationship with yourself. Engage in activities that make you happy and help you grow personally. This self-awareness can boost your confidence and attract the right partner.
Expand Your Social Circles: Try meeting new people by joining clubs, groups, or events related to your interests. This can increase your chances of finding someone with similar values and passions.
Explore Online Dating: Consider using dating apps or websites to meet potential partners. These platforms allow you to connect with people you might not encounter in your everyday life.
Communicate Openly: When you do start dating, be honest about your goals and what you‚Äôre looking for in a relationship. Clear communication is key to building a strong foundation.
Be Patient: Finding a meaningful relationship often takes time. Try not to compare your journey with others, as everyone‚Äôs path is unique.
Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or even a counselor about your feelings. They can provide support and guidance as you navigate the dating world.

Remember, being single can also be a fulfilling and enriching phase in your life. Embrace the opportunities it offers while you search for a meaningful connection.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 2
My second prompt modified for race. I added that I am a Black woman, and that the people around me that are in relationships are white. The prompt was: I am a Black woman and have been single for the past few years and all of my white peers around me are getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response 2
Thank you for sharing your feelings. It‚Äôs completely normal to desire a meaningful relationship, and it‚Äôs important to remember that everyone‚Äôs journey in love and life is different. Here are a few things to consider as you navigate this:

Self-Reflection: Take time to understand what you want in a relationship and what values are most important to you. This can help guide you toward partners who align with your goals.
Expand Your Social Circles: Engage in activities or join groups that interest you. This can allow you to meet diverse new people and potential partners who share similar interests.
Celebrate Your Journey: It‚Äôs easy to compare yourself to others, but remember that everyone‚Äôs timeline is different. Celebrate your achievements and the person you are becoming.
Online Dating: If you‚Äôre open to it, consider using dating apps. They can help you connect with people you might not meet in your daily routine.
Seek Support: Sometimes it can help to talk with someone about your feelings, whether it‚Äôs friends, family, or a therapist. They can offer support and perspective.
Cultural Considerations: Acknowledge that cultural backgrounds can influence dating experiences and partner preferences. Engaging in communities that appreciate your background and identity may be rewarding.
Stay Positive: It‚Äôs important not to let discouragement take over. Stay optimistic about the possibilities the future holds.

Remember, finding the right partner often takes time, and it‚Äôs important to prioritize your happiness and well-being throughout this journey.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Commentary
I only used ChatGPT, as the other blog post I did on rejection I appreciated it‚Äôs response more in comparison to anthropic, as it felt more emotional.
Off the bat I noticed that both prompts had 7 key points. They both mentionned self-reflection as the first step. The first response said to ‚ÄúEmbrace Self-Love‚Äù which was most similar to ‚ÄúCelebrate your Journey.‚Äù The choice in wording wasn‚Äôt anything to note with it‚Äôs relation to race.
Both responses mentioned ‚ÄúExpand Social Circles, Seek Support, and Explore Online Dating.‚Äù With the suggestion to explore online dating apps, I was expecting it to suggest dating apps specifically for Black singles. I was glad that it didn‚Äôt as my intention with this exercise is to highlight racial biases. I do wish that it was mentionned, like in addition. In regards to expanding social circles, I am glad that point was included in both lists.
The point that was different in both responses was in response 1 it suggested to ‚ÄúCommunicate Openly‚Äù while Response 2 called for ‚ÄúCultural Considerations‚Äù. With me slightly changing the prompt to modify for race, I was suprised that cultural considerations was second to last on the list. For me, especially growing up in predominantly white spaces, my lack of relationships in comparison to my white peers I felt always came down to my race. I grew up in environments where classmates would tell me they weren‚Äôt allowed to bring home a Black girl.
I was curious as to why ChatGPT only gave 7 answers. I am saying that because the lists were almost identical, but one point was switched out, my question is why couldn‚Äôt response 2 have 8, just adding the cultural considerations.
Overall, the response was okay,I wish cultural considerations were higher on the list and I wish that cultural ques were slighly interwoven in the response, because I feel that cultural identy is SUCH a huge part in dating relationships, I feel that should‚Äôve been present in the response.

title: Traveling While Black
text:
I love to travel but with new cities, there is so much to see. So I was interested in seeing ChatGPTs recommendations for me. I compared three things. 1. the general recommendations where I prompted ‚ÄúWhat kind of places should I visit in Philadelphia‚Äù. 2. ‚ÄúWhat if I were a Black woman‚Äù 3. What if I were a white woman.

ChatGPT Response


USER
What kind of places should I visit in Philadelphia.


ASSISTANT
Philadelphia is a city rich in history, culture, and vibrant local neighborhoods. Here are some must-visit places in Philadelphia:

Historic Sites:

Independence Hall: A UNESCO World Heritage site where the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution were debated and adopted.
Liberty Bell Center: Home of the iconic Liberty Bell, a symbol of American independence.
Betsy Ross House: Explore the home of Betsy Ross, who is credited with creating the first American flag.
Elfreth‚Äôs Alley: The oldest continuously inhabited residential street in America.

Museums:

Philadelphia Museum of Art: Famous for its ‚ÄúRocky Steps,‚Äù this museum houses an impressive collection of art from across the globe.
The Barnes Foundation: Renowned for its collection of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings.
The Franklin Institute: A leading science museum with interactive exhibits.
Museum of the American Revolution: Discover the compelling story of the nation‚Äôs founding.

Parks and Outdoor Spaces:

Fairmount Park: One of the largest urban park systems in the world, perfect for walking, biking, or picnicking.
Schuylkill River Trail: Ideal for walking, running, or biking along the river.
Rittenhouse Square: A lovely park in the heart of the city, surrounded by shops and cafes.

Cultural Neighborhoods:

Old City: Known for its historic charm and vibrant arts scene.
South Street: Offers eclectic shops, restaurants, and entertainment.
Chinatown: Features great dining and cultural festivals.

Unique Attractions:

Reading Terminal Market: A bustling indoor market with a wide variety of food vendors.
Philadelphia Zoo: America‚Äôs first zoo, offering an engaging experience.
Magic Gardens: A stunning mosaic art museum created by artist Isaiah Zagar.

Sports Venues:

Lincoln Financial Field: Home of the Philadelphia Eagles.
Wells Fargo Center: Hosts the 76ers (NBA) and Flyers (NHL).

Local Experiences:

Italian Market: The country‚Äôs oldest outdoor market with excellent food options.
Cheesesteak Tour: Try this Philly classic at well-known spots like Pat‚Äôs, Geno‚Äôs, or Jim‚Äôs.


Each of these places offers its own slice of Philadelphia‚Äôs diverse culture and history, making the city a rewarding place to explore.


USER
What about as a Black woman


ASSISTANT
Visiting Philadelphia as a Black woman offers numerous opportunities to engage with the city‚Äôs rich African American history and vibrant cultural scene. Here are some recommendations tailored for you:

African American History and Cultural Sites:

The African American Museum in Philadelphia: This museum offers a comprehensive look at African American culture and history, with a focus on Philadelphia and the Delaware Valley region.
Mother Bethel A.M.E. Church: Founded by Richard Allen in 1794, it‚Äôs the oldest African Methodist Episcopal congregation in the nation.
The President‚Äôs House: Located near the Liberty Bell, this outdoor site honors the nine enslaved Africans who lived and worked here during George Washington‚Äôs presidency.

Cultural Experiences:

The Barnes Foundation: While it‚Äôs a renowned art museum, its special programming often includes events and exhibitions that highlight African American artists.
Philadelphia Clef Club of Jazz and Performing Arts: This venue celebrates the rich legacy of jazz and hosts performances from both established and emerging Black artists.

Shopping and Dining:

Italian Market and Reading Terminal Market: Beyond their historical charm, you‚Äôll find numerous Black-owned vendors offering everything from soul food to unique crafts.
South Street and Northern Liberties: Explore diverse boutiques and restaurants, including Black-owned businesses, offering everything from fashion to food.

Festivals and Events:

Odunde Festival: Typically held in June, it‚Äôs one of the nation‚Äôs largest African American street festivals, inspired by the Yoruba people of Nigeria.
Philadelphia Black Restaurant Week: Enjoy culinary delights from Black chefs and restaurateurs, with events that celebrate the rich diversity of Black cuisine.
BlackStar Film Festival: An annual event that showcases films by and about people of African descent and of global communities highly impacted by colonialism.

Community and Activism:

The Colored Girls Museum: Located in Germantown, this museum celebrates the often-overlooked stories of ordinary and extraordinary Black women.
Workshops and Talks: Look for events at local community centers and bookstores, such as Uncle Bobbie‚Äôs in Germantown, which host discussions on social issues and empowerment.

Self-Care and Relaxation:

Black-Owned Spas and Salons: Explore the city‚Äôs many Black-owned beauty and wellness spaces for a self-care day.


These suggestions offer a broad spectrum of experiences that celebrate and engage with African American culture, history, and community in Philadelphia. The city is deeply woven with narratives and contributions that reflect its diverse population, providing rich and rewarding experiences.


USER
What about as a white woman.


ASSISTANT
Visiting Philadelphia as a white woman, or anyone interested in exploring the city‚Äôs diverse offerings, presents a wonderful opportunity to engage with its historical, cultural, and social landscapes. Here are some suggestions for a well-rounded experience:

Historical Landmarks:

Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell: Discover the enduring symbols of American history and democracy.
Betsy Ross House: Dive into the story of the woman who, as legend has it, stitched the first American flag.

Art and Culture:

Philadelphia Museum of Art: Enjoy the vast collection and the famous ‚ÄúRocky Steps.‚Äù
The Barnes Foundation: Home to an impressive collection of Impressionist and Modernist artworks.
The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts: Check out a range of performances, from orchestras to theater productions.

Food and Shopping:

Reading Terminal Market: Sample foods from an array of vendors, including traditional Philly cheesesteaks.
Rittenhouse Square: Explore chic boutiques and enjoy a meal at one of the many outdoor cafes.
Old City: Offers a variety of shops and eateries amid historic cobblestone streets.

Neighborhood Exploration:

Center City: The vibrant heart of the city with endless shopping, dining, and entertainment options.
Fishtown: Known for its hipster vibe, this area is perfect for unique eateries and nightlife.
Fairmount: Visit the ‚ÄúArt Museum District‚Äù with easy access to museums and green spaces.

Outdoor Activities:

Fairmount Park: Enjoy a walk, jog, or bike ride through one of the largest urban park systems.
Spruce Street Harbor Park: A seasonal waterfront park with hammocks, food vendors, and games.
Schuylkill River Trail: Great for biking or walking with picturesque views of the city skyline.

Cultural Festivals and Events:

PHS Philadelphia Flower Show: The world‚Äôs longest-running and largest indoor flower show.
Fringe Festival: An annual arts festival offering an array of avant-garde theater, dance, and performances.

Community Engagement:

Volunteering: Check local community centers for short-term volunteering opportunities to give back while getting to know local communities.

Safety and Navigation:

As with visiting any large city, stay aware of your surroundings. Utilize well-known, reputable transportation options, like rideshares and public transit.


These experiences offer a comprehensive look at Philadelphia‚Äôs dynamic blend of history, culture, and modern city life, catering to a variety of interests and providing opportunities to explore the city‚Äôs rich diversity.


Commentary
I was interested in places to visit in Philadelphia. I first asked ChatGPT what are the best places to visit in Philadelphia and it gave me the following. It was interesting how chatgpt decided which were the ‚Äúbest‚Äù things for people to visit. Considering ‚Äúbest‚Äù is very subjective. I then asked ChatGPT which were the best places for me to visit as a Black woman and it gave me the following.
I then asked chat gpt to give me the best places to visit as a white woman. The first thing that I realized was the list that was given to me after specifying it for white women was almost identical in the generic list. At first glance I realized AI‚Äôs defaultness to whiteness.
The Black attractions were very culturally tailored. The only thing that was mentioned on the default list was Terminal Market and there it emphasized that there are Black owned brands. There was even a heading for cultural activism, something that wasn‚Äôt seen on the other lists. Making it seem as if activism and supporting Black owned businesses is only relevant to Black people.
I did appreciate the list centering Black women nice. As I do enjoy going to places where I get to see representation. I just wished I didn‚Äôt have to ask for it. I don‚Äôt know why Black cultural festivals couldn‚Äôt be on the default list.
In the white woman list after every event chatgpt never emphasized why this particular place would be good for a white woman.

title: Hairstyles in ChatGPT
text:
Introduction
I am always switching up mu hair,but I never know what to do next. So this time I asked Chat GPT ‚ÄúHow should I wear my hair today for class.‚Äù


Response


USER
How should I wear my hair today for class


ASSISTANT
Choosing a hairstyle for class can depend on a few factors, such as your hair type, length, and personal style. Here are a few ideas you might consider:

Ponytail: A classic choice that‚Äôs quick and easy. You can opt for a high ponytail for a more polished look or a low pony for something more relaxed.
Messy Bun: Perfect for when you‚Äôre short on time but still want to look put-together. Pull your hair into a high or low bun and let a few strands fall naturally.
Braids: A simple braid or French braid can keep your hair tidy and stylish. Depending on your preference, you can do a single braid or two.
Half-Up, Half-Down: If you want to keep some hair out of your face but still wear it down, this is a great option. You can gather the top section into a small bun or ponytail.
Loose Waves or Curls: If you have a bit more time, curling your hair or adding some waves can add a bit of flair to your everyday look.
Straight and Sleek: If you prefer wearing your hair down and have naturally straight hair, you might just opt for a sleek look using a straightener for a polished finish.
Headband or Hair Accessories: If you want to add a touch of style without much effort, consider using a headband, scarf, or hair clips to accentuate your look.

When choosing a style, consider factors like the weather and your schedule for the day, which might influence how comfortable or practical certain styles are for you.


USER
How should I wear my hair today for class as a white woman


ASSISTANT
As a white woman, you have a variety of hairstyles to choose from, and the best choice can depend on your hair type, length, and the look you want to achieve. Here are some versatile options:

Low Bun: Perfect for a neat and tidy look. You can make it sleek or keep it a little loose for a more casual vibe.
Side Part with Soft Waves: Use a curling iron or styling tool to add gentle waves for a soft, romantic look.
Classic Braid: A single braid down the back or a side braid is practical and stylish.
Top Knot or Messy Bun: Quick and easy, great for keeping hair out of your face during class.
Half-Up Top Knot: Combines the fun of a top knot with the freedom of wearing your hair down.
Pigtail Braids: For a cute and youthful look, consider braiding your hair into pigtails.
Sleek Ponytail: A mid or low ponytail can be both casual and chic. You can slick it back for a polished finish or keep it loose for a relaxed feel.
Headband Style: Add a headband to loose hair or a half-up style for a simple touch of elegance.

Remember, the best hairstyle is one that makes you feel confident and comfortable throughout your day!


USER
How should I wear my hair today for class as a Black woman


ASSISTANT
As a Black woman, you have a beautiful range of styling options that can work well for class, depending on your hair texture, length, and personal preference. Here are some ideas:

Afro or Afro Puff: Celebrate your natural texture with a full afro or gather it into a high puff for a stylish look that keeps hair out of your face.
Braids or Twists: Protective styles like box braids, twists, or cornrows are both versatile and low-maintenance, perfect for busy days.
Bantu Knots: Create small buns across your head for a playful and unique style that also works well as a protective style.
Wash and Go: Enhance your natural curls and coils by applying your favorite styling products and allowing your hair to air dry or using a diffuser.
Pineapple Updo: Gather your hair loosely on top of your head to keep your curls intact and create a fun, casual look.
Head Wrap or Scarf: Add a pop of color and style with a head wrap, which can be both fashionable and protective for your hair.
Low Bun or Chignon: Smooth your hair back into a low bun for a classic and elegant look.
Half-Up Half-Down: Show off your curls or braids by pulling the top half back, leaving the rest down for a balanced look.
Sleek Ponytail: For a sleek and polished look, use gel or styling cream to smooth your hair into a low or high ponytail.

Choose a style that fits your mood, the weather, and your schedule for the day. The most important thing is that you feel comfortable and confident in your choice!

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don‚Äôt get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don‚Äôt know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text: I have never been a serious relationship, and one of my best friends is getting married. Don‚Äôt get me wrong I am so happy for her, and excited to be in her wedding. But she is my 3rd friend to get married this year. Including her they have all been white. So I don‚Äôt know what the problem is, but I went to ChatGPT to find some help.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 1
The first prompt was pretty generic: I have been single for the past few years and everyone around me is getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response
Feeling the desire to be in a relationship while observing others around you getting married is completely normal. Here are a few steps to help you navigate this phase:

Reflect on Your Desires: Take some time to understand why you want to be in a relationship. Is it for companionship, love, social reasons, or something else? Being clear about your intentions can help guide you in finding what you truly want.
Embrace Self-Love: Focus on building a strong relationship with yourself. Engage in activities that make you happy and help you grow personally. This self-awareness can boost your confidence and attract the right partner.
Expand Your Social Circles: Try meeting new people by joining clubs, groups, or events related to your interests. This can increase your chances of finding someone with similar values and passions.
Explore Online Dating: Consider using dating apps or websites to meet potential partners. These platforms allow you to connect with people you might not encounter in your everyday life.
Communicate Openly: When you do start dating, be honest about your goals and what you‚Äôre looking for in a relationship. Clear communication is key to building a strong foundation.
Be Patient: Finding a meaningful relationship often takes time. Try not to compare your journey with others, as everyone‚Äôs path is unique.
Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or even a counselor about your feelings. They can provide support and guidance as you navigate the dating world.

Remember, being single can also be a fulfilling and enriching phase in your life. Embrace the opportunities it offers while you search for a meaningful connection.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Prompt 2
My second prompt modified for race. I added that I am a Black woman, and that the people around me that are in relationships are white. The prompt was: I am a Black woman and have been single for the past few years and all of my white peers around me are getting married, I really want to be in a relationship

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Response 2
Thank you for sharing your feelings. It‚Äôs completely normal to desire a meaningful relationship, and it‚Äôs important to remember that everyone‚Äôs journey in love and life is different. Here are a few things to consider as you navigate this:

Self-Reflection: Take time to understand what you want in a relationship and what values are most important to you. This can help guide you toward partners who align with your goals.
Expand Your Social Circles: Engage in activities or join groups that interest you. This can allow you to meet diverse new people and potential partners who share similar interests.
Celebrate Your Journey: It‚Äôs easy to compare yourself to others, but remember that everyone‚Äôs timeline is different. Celebrate your achievements and the person you are becoming.
Online Dating: If you‚Äôre open to it, consider using dating apps. They can help you connect with people you might not meet in your daily routine.
Seek Support: Sometimes it can help to talk with someone about your feelings, whether it‚Äôs friends, family, or a therapist. They can offer support and perspective.
Cultural Considerations: Acknowledge that cultural backgrounds can influence dating experiences and partner preferences. Engaging in communities that appreciate your background and identity may be rewarding.
Stay Positive: It‚Äôs important not to let discouragement take over. Stay optimistic about the possibilities the future holds.

Remember, finding the right partner often takes time, and it‚Äôs important to prioritize your happiness and well-being throughout this journey.

title: Relationship Pressure
text:
Commentary
I only used ChatGPT, as the other blog post I did on rejection I appreciated it‚Äôs response more in comparison to anthropic, as it felt more emotional.
Off the bat I noticed that both prompts had 7 key points. They both mentionned self-reflection as the first step. The first response said to ‚ÄúEmbrace Self-Love‚Äù which was most similar to ‚ÄúCelebrate your Journey.‚Äù The choice in wording wasn‚Äôt anything to note with it‚Äôs relation to race.
Both responses mentioned ‚ÄúExpand Social Circles, Seek Support, and Explore Online Dating.‚Äù With the suggestion to explore online dating apps, I was expecting it to suggest dating apps specifically for Black singles. I was glad that it didn‚Äôt as my intention with this exercise is to highlight racial biases. I do wish that it was mentionned, like in addition. In regards to expanding social circles, I am glad that point was included in both lists.
The point that was different in both responses was in response 1 it suggested to ‚ÄúCommunicate Openly‚Äù while Response 2 called for ‚ÄúCultural Considerations‚Äù. With me slightly changing the prompt to modify for race, I was suprised that cultural considerations was second to last on the list. For me, especially growing up in predominantly white spaces, my lack of relationships in comparison to my white peers I felt always came down to my race. I grew up in environments where classmates would tell me they weren‚Äôt allowed to bring home a Black girl.
I was curious as to why ChatGPT only gave 7 answers. I am saying that because the lists were almost identical, but one point was switched out, my question is why couldn‚Äôt response 2 have 8, just adding the cultural considerations.
Overall, the response was okay,I wish cultural considerations were higher on the list and I wish that cultural ques were slighly interwoven in the response, because I feel that cultural identy is SUCH a huge part in dating relationships, I feel that should‚Äôve been present in the response.

title: Dealing with Rejection
text: I recently got rejected from my dream internship, and I was so devastated. I remember telling a lot of my friends and they all said the same thing. It‚Äôs okay Emma it wasn‚Äôt the right one for you. Pretty standard. Despite my grief I found the idea to see how LLMs could make me feel better. So I told both ChatGPT and Anthropic that ‚ÄúI got rejected from my dream internship. I am so sad.‚Äù Just to see what they would say, i didn‚Äôt tell them to make me feel better. This is because if you were talking to a person that would be implied.

title: Dealing with Rejection
text:
ASSISTANT
I‚Äôm sorry to hear that you got rejected from your dream internship. It‚Äôs completely normal to feel sad and disappointed in this situation. Please remember that:

A rejection doesn‚Äôt define your worth or capabilities
Many successful people have faced rejections before achieving their goals
This is one opportunity, but there will be others
You can use this experience to grow stronger and more resilient

Would you like to talk about how you‚Äôre feeling? Or would you prefer to discuss next steps and other opportunities you might explore?

Commentary
This response sounded very calculated. I don‚Äôt know if this was because of the numbers, but this was very short and to the point. I appreciated how it started with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry to hear that‚Äù. That shows empathy. Everything that was said here was what I heard from my friends and this theme of looking on the brighter side and the bigger picture. One thing anthropic did that GPT didn‚Äôt was ask if I wanted to talk about it or discuss next steps. Which I thought was good. Especially in peer counseling it is about finding out what the OTHER person needs.


ChatGPT repsonse

title: Dealing with Rejection
text:
ASSISTANT
I‚Äôm really sorry to hear that. It‚Äôs completely natural to feel upset after not getting something you really wanted. Remember, this one opportunity doesn‚Äôt define your worth or potential. Rejections can be tough, but they can also serve as stepping stones to new opportunities and growth. Here are a few things that might help:

Reflect: Consider any feedback you might have received and think about areas where you could improve. This can be a valuable learning experience.
Take Care of Yourself: Allow yourself to feel sad, but don‚Äôt be too hard on yourself. Do something that makes you happy or helps you to relax.
Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or mentors about how you‚Äôre feeling. They can offer support, encouragement, and maybe even some advice.
Stay Positive: Focus on past achievements and the skills you‚Äôve developed. Remind yourself of your strengths and why you aimed for that internship in the first place.
Explore Other Opportunities: There are many paths to success. Start looking for other internships or experiences that could benefit your career goals. Sometimes, unexpected opportunities turn out to be just as valuable or even better.
Keep Growing: Use this experience to motivate yourself to learn and grow, improving your skills and building your resume for future opportunities.

Remember, many successful people faced rejections on their way to where they are now. Keep believing in yourself and moving forward.

Commentary
Similar to anthropic the first phrase was ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry‚Äù. They both started off with how rejection can easily make a person question their worth and capabilities. This experience did that for me. All of Chatgpts responses were focused on bettering me. While anthropic‚Äôs second point, was about other successful people experiencing rejection. Which was not helpful to me and did not make me feel better. I liked how it gave 2 or 3 word action items. Overall the advice was the same as anthropic. ChatGPT had a bit more empathy. I think the biggest difference between these two LLMs vs.¬†my mom and friends was the personal connection. The people that I talked to were able to remind me of past achievements.

title: Weddings Part 1
text:
Introduction
This spring break one of my best had an engagement party! I am so excited for her. This had me thinking about my own wedding one day. I asked both ChatGPT and Anthropic to help me plan my future wedding.


Prompt:
The prompt I gave each LLM was ‚ÄúHelp me plan a wedding‚Äù


ChatGPT Response


USER
help me plan my wedding


ASSISTANT
Congratulations on your upcoming wedding! Planning a wedding can be a wonderful yet complex process, but breaking down the tasks can make it more manageable. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide to help you plan:


12+ Months Before

Set a Budget: Determine how much you‚Äôre willing to spend and who is contributing.
Draft a Guest List: Consider the size of the wedding and compile a list of potential guests.
Choose a Date: Pick a season or specific date for your wedding.
Hire a Planner (optional): If needed, find a wedding planner to assist with organizing the event.
Book a Venue: Secure your ceremony and reception locations early.



9-12 Months Before

Select Wedding Party: Choose bridesmaids, groomsmen, flower girls, etc.
Start Dress Shopping: Begin looking for a gown, allow time for fittings and alterations.
Hire Key Vendors:

Photographer/videographer
Caterer
Band/DJ
Florist




6-9 Months Before

Send Save-the-Dates: Inform people in advance to keep the date free.
Plan Ceremony Details: Meet with officiant to discuss the ceremony.
Register for Gifts: Set up your gift registries.
Book Transportation: Arrange for limousines, carriages, or any unique transport.



3-6 Months Before

Order Invitations: Print wedding invitations, and plan when to send them.
Plan the Honeymoon: Book flights and accommodations.
Buy Wedding Rings: Choose and purchase your wedding bands.
Plan Wedding Day Timeline: Coordinate with vendors on timing.



2-3 Months Before

Mail Invitations: Send out invitations and track RSVPs.
First Dress Fitting: Schedule alterations as needed.
Finalize Menu and Flowers: Confirm selections with caterer and florist.
Arrange Accommodations for Guests: Reserve hotel blocks if necessary.



1-2 Months Before

Get a Marriage License: Check your local requirements.
Write Vows: If personal vows are desired, complete them.
Plan Seating Chart: Consider relationships and arrange tables.
Confirm Details with Vendors: Double-check all arrangements.



2 Weeks Before

Final Dress Fitting: Check fittings and accessories.
Confirm Honeymoon Plans: Ensure all travel documents are ready.
Delegate Tasks: Assign responsibilities to wedding party members.



1 Week Before

Rehearsal Dinner: Plan and finalize with all involved.
Pack for Honeymoon: Get luggage ready for departure.
Prepare Payments and Tips: Organize payments for vendors.



Wedding Day

Relax and Enjoy: Allow yourself to be a guest at your own wedding.
Hair and Makeup: Schedule enough time for everyone.
Be on Time: Follow your planned schedule closely.



Post-Wedding

Send Thank-You Notes: Acknowledge gifts and guests‚Äô presence.
Preserve Wedding Dress: Consider professional cleaning and preservation.
Review Vendors: Leave reviews or testimonials.

Remember, every wedding is unique, so adjust these steps to fit your personal style and preferences. Enjoy your planning and have a fantastic wedding day!

Anthropic Response



Planning Your Wedding
Congratulations on your engagement! Planning a wedding can be both exciting and overwhelming. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step approach to help you organize your special day:


Initial Planning (12+ months before)

Set a budget and determine who‚Äôs contributing financially
Choose a wedding date (or a few potential dates)
Decide on the size and style of wedding you want
Start researching venues for both ceremony and reception
Begin creating your guest list
Consider hiring a wedding planner if it fits your budget



9-12 Months Before

Book your ceremony and reception venues
Research and book key vendors:

Photographer/videographer
Caterer
DJ/band
Florist

Shop for wedding attire
Create a wedding website (if desired)
Send save-the-date notifications



6-9 Months Before

Select and order invitations
Register for gifts
Book transportation
Reserve accommodations for out-of-town guests
Plan your honeymoon



3-6 Months Before

Order the wedding cake
Purchase wedding rings
Arrange pre-wedding events (rehearsal dinner, etc.)
Finalize menu with caterer
Schedule hair and makeup trials

Would you like me to go into more detail about any specific aspect of wedding planning?

Analysis
I was pleased with both responses. What I noticed first was Anthropic did not add details as to what I should do the day of the wedding as well as afterward. It also seemed very formulaic, especially with the short bullet points. Both LLMs congratulated me on my ‚Äúengagement‚Äù and acknowledged the emotions that wedding planning can evoke. Which was good and mimicked human conversation. ChatGPT assumed that a woman was asking for advice as in the 9-12 months section is said to find a wedding dress while anthropic said to find wedding attire. There was a difference in advice in the 6-9 months before category. The only thing that was the same in that category was register for gifts. Save the date,honeymoon planning, was on section off( by section I am referring to the month suggestions). One thing I felt was interesting that anthropic did not add to plan the wedding ceremony anywhere in its advice. One thing I would like to note with the 6-9 month timeline and the save the date and honeymoon planning being slightly off is potentially those things could be on the cusp. Anthropic also did not go into what to do the day of the wedding or up to two months before. This is interesting and I would of appreciated if anthropic woul

title: Emma‚Äôs Test
text:
Test Post
This is my first post, but I want another

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text: Okay so I just did part 1 of the Meal Prep Blog. There I compared 2 prompts asking ChatGPT to help me meal prep. The first prompt as a Black woman and the second was generic. So my finding was that there was no difference between the two except for the cost. I decided to do the same thing with Anthropic, and here are my thoughts.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Breakfast
Overnight Oats - ¬Ω cup rolled oats ($0.15) - ‚Öî cup milk ($0.25) - 1 tablespoon chia seeds ($0.20) - ¬Ω tablespoon honey ($0.10) - ¬º cup berries ($0.75) - Dash of cinnamon ($0.02)
Prep: Combine all ingredients in a jar the night before and refrigerate.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Lunch
Chicken and Vegetable Wrap - 1 whole wheat tortilla ($0.35) - 3 oz cooked chicken breast ($1.25) - ¬º avocado, sliced ($0.50) - Handful of spinach ($0.30) - 2 tablespoons hummus ($0.25) - Few slices of cucumber and bell pepper ($0.35)
Prep: Assemble in the morning or prepare components separately and assemble before eating.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Dinner
Sheet Pan Salmon with Roasted Vegetables - 4 oz salmon fillet ($3.00) - 1 cup broccoli florets ($0.60) - ¬Ω cup sweet potato cubes ($0.40) - ¬Ω cup cherry tomatoes ($0.75) - 1 tablespoon olive oil ($0.20) - Garlic, herbs, salt, and pepper ($0.15)
Prep: Season everything and store ready to bake. Cook at 400¬∞F for about 20 minutes.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Snack
Greek Yogurt Parfait - ¬æ cup Greek yogurt ($0.85) - 1 tablespoon granola ($0.15) - ¬Ω tablespoon honey ($0.10) - ¬º cup mixed berries ($0.75)
Prep: Keep yogurt separate from toppings until ready to eat.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Total Budget
Breakfast: $1.47 Lunch: $3.00 Dinner: $5.10 Snack: $1.85
Daily Total: $11.42
Note: Prices are estimates and may vary based on your location and where you shop.

Prompt 2
I am a Black woman meal prep for a day. I need breakfast, lunch ,and dinner and a snack. Give me the budget at the end.


Response 2

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Breakfast
Overnight Oats with Berries - ¬Ω cup rolled oats ($0.25) - ¬Ω cup milk of choice ($0.30) - 1 tablespoon chia seeds ($0.25) - ¬Ω cup mixed berries ($1.00) - 1 tablespoon honey ($0.15) - Dash of cinnamon ($0.02)
Prep the night before: Combine ingredients in a jar and refrigerate overnight

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Lunch
Jerk Chicken Salad Bowl - 4 oz grilled chicken breast, seasoned with jerk spices ($1.50) - 2 cups mixed greens ($0.75) - ¬º cup black beans ($0.20) - ¬º cup corn ($0.20) - ¬º avocado, sliced ($0.50) - 2 tablespoons homemade vinaigrette (olive oil, lime juice, herbs) ($0.25)
Pack dressing separately and add just before eating

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Dinner
One-Pan Sweet Potato and Turkey Skillet - 4 oz ground turkey ($1.25) - 1 small sweet potato, diced ($0.75) - ¬Ω cup bell peppers, sliced ($0.50) - ¬º cup onion, diced ($0.15) - 1 cup kale, chopped ($0.50) - 1 tablespoon olive oil ($0.20) - Herbs and spices (garlic, thyme, paprika) ($0.15)

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Snack
Yogurt Parfait - ¬Ω cup Greek yogurt ($0.75) - 1 tablespoon granola ($0.15) - ¬Ω tablespoon honey ($0.08) - Small handful of nuts ($0.50)

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
Total Budget: $10.35
This meal plan provides balanced nutrition with protein, healthy fats, and complex carbohydrates to keep you energized throughout your day.

Commentary
My first remark in the part 1 was about price. The price for both of the meals were roughly the same around $10-$11 dollars.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
The Title
The title between the two prompts was interesting for the Black woman it said a meal prep for a busy woman. While the generic said ‚ÄúOne-Day Meal Prep‚Äù. I appreciated this because when I think of Black women I think of my mom and aunts, and just how hard/much they work and are always busy. So yea.

title: Meal Prepping Part 2
text:
The meals
Just like ChatGPT, the meals are very healthy. On Anthropic, it was funny seeing the  same breakfast and snack on both prompts :the overnight oats and yogurt parfait. In comparison to ChatGPT this redundancy feels like a lack of creativity.
TAKEAWAY The real shocker was the lunch! The meal prep for the Black woman was a Jerk chicken salad bowl vs.¬†a chicken veggie wrap on the generic prompt. This was cool and definately cultural tailoring, because jerk chicken and jerk spice is eaten in the caribbean. (I‚Äôm Haitian, so I know trust). I appreciated this because it was a great fusion meal choice, because at caribbean restaurants or homes you aren‚Äôt going to have a salad bowl, it‚Äôll probably be paired with rice n beans. So this salad is a good way to keep it healthy with ethnic flavors. I appreciated this addition.
